content.rendered:
Years ago, a friend told me that we base our decisions on the information that we have at the time. One problem is that we often don’t know how much we don’t know. At least that has been my experience.

I cannot remember all of the mistakes that I’ve made: big and small. I’ve tried to learn from them what I could in hopes of not repeating them, or at least not in the same way. Unfortunately, it doesn’t always work.

It’s easier to see how much others might not know, at least after we’ve gotten a little more experience in a particular area or interest. Still, there is always going to be someone who knows more than we do, or at least thinks that he does.

Proverbs 11:14 (KJV) reminds us that, “Where there is no counsel, the people fall;
But in the multitude of counselors there is safety.”

There can be wisdom found in asking others for help, but not always. There will be times when others don’t know the answer that we are seeking anymore than we do. But it never hurts to try. As they say, the only bad question is the one that we don’t ask.

Not knowing, or not having the knowledge that we need can affect every part of our lives. Knowing, on the other hand, doesn’t truly help unless we are willing and able to properly apply what we know to any given situation. Often, we know right from wrong, but it can be far too easy to just follow our emotions, in spite of what we know.

“If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him.” — James 1:5 (KJV)

We never do get to a point in our lives when we always make the right choice. Yet, we can learn from both our successes and our failures. Hopefully, we repeat the things that work, as needed, and avoid the things that don’t. In the end, God is the only one who can judge right from wrong.
